title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds under Section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act authorizes the Secretary to reduce overpayments by the amount of past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts upon receiving notice from the State judicial branch or designated State agency. The Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount of State judicial debts, pay the reduced amount to the State judicial branch or agency, and notify the person of the offset. If a joint return is involved, a notice will be sent. The Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount of State judicial debts and notify the person of the offset. If a joint return is involved, a notice will be sent with the necessary details. The Secretary can reduce overpayments for various types of debts before crediting the overpayment. The Secretary can reduce overpayments for State income tax and unemployment compensation debts before applying them to future Federal tax liabilities. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies, overpayments will be applied in the order they accrued. When a person owes multiple debts to State agencies or the State judicial branch, any overpayment will be applied to those debts in the order they were accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for debt consideration. "Past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt" refers to debts resulting from court judgments or sentences. The term 'past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt' refers to debts resulting from court judgments or sentences rendered by a court handling criminal or traffic cases in the State, where an amount is determined to be due and remains uncollected. The term 'State judicial debt' includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to victims of crime resulting from court judgments in criminal or traffic cases. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due State judicial debts. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due State judicial debts, specifying required information and procedures for reduction of debts. Regulations may include fees to reimburse the Secretary for applying the reduction procedure. The regulations may require State judicial branches and State agencies to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for applying the reduction procedure. Any erroneous payment made to a State judicial branch or State agency must be promptly repaid to the Secretary. The State judicial branches or State agencies must promptly repay any erroneous payments to the Secretary as required by regulations.
